slides.title: Review: Rating results in a set of costs
slides.originalNotes:
Review: Rating results in a set of costs
The rating engine can be Guidewire Rating Management or a third-party system that receives information about a policy transaction and returns a list of costs for that transactiom Rating inputs are the values that the end user provides. The rating engine uses the values to calculate costs, which are created when a policy is rated, and a quote is generated.

For some types of policies, additional information may be used during rating. For example, in a workers' comp policy, the cost of covered employees are rated using the class code and payroll information. Basically, any data that that affects the premium of a policy can be used in rating.

slides.title: Costs
slides.originalNotes:
Costs
Cost is the discrete unit of price for anything for a specific period of time. The total cost of a policy is the sum of the individual costs.

Premium costs are costs for items on the policy, such as the cost of a line coverage)

Non-premium costs are costs that are charged to the policy holder but are not charges for coverages. They are usually taxes or surcharges such as processing fees for a multi-installment payment plan that are directly applied to the amount of premium being charged.

General Liability exposure and coverage submission
This example shows two versions of basis scalable general liability (GL) policies where the exposure basis is dollars of sales. The adjusted rate is an example of the adjustment to the base rate. Note that the rating engine will determine which exposures are rate scalable and which are basis scalable. In this case, we are assuming a basis scalable scenario. See the product documentation for more specifics about the rating engine strategy for general liability exposures.

The term abasis scalable" refers to something priced according to a term amount of the value being insured. The term amount is the premium or cost calculated for the basis amount for the term. If the YEARLY sales are $500,000, but the policy term is 6 months, the Basis is scaled to $250,00 — that is the value at risk for the term.

By default, the basis' value is "1“ for rate scalable material objects such as cars and homes. However, some exposure-based coverages are calculated from amounts like payroll or sales (e.g., general liability or workers’ compensation policies). In this example, the basis is a sales amount.

A term amount is the adjusted rate multiplied by the basis (full rate term premium). Basis-rated coverages per premium rate/basis amount.

slides.originalNotes:
How are these values determined?
By default, the basis' value is "1“ for material objects such as cars and homes. However, some exposure coverages are activated with amounts like payroll or sales (e.g. GL and workers' compensation), but not all. Some GL exposures use a rate scalable value.

Note that some premium calculations will require a hybrid approach. For example, a basis of "square feet of building" is not scaled for the term so will require pro rata adjustment even though the Term Amount is calculated from a basis * adjusted rate.

slides.title: Financial transactions: Example
slides.originalNotes:
Financial transactions: Example
The simplest case of a financial transaction is when a new policy is submitted and there is no previous version. A submission is one way to initiate the transaction, but changes to the policy also invoke a financial transaction. The financial transaction is defined as the cost of the difference betueen costs for the current and previous policies as the initial cost (submission) for a portion of a policy (e.g., full-term cost of collision on a single policy).

In this example, a policy change results in cost changes. The collision costs increase by $16 while the comprehensive costs do not change at all. The difference in subsequent costs is what makes it a financial transaction.

slides.title: Example: Personal Auto Coverage Change fa
slides.originalNotes:
Example: Personal Auto Coverage Change
In this example, we are looking at an auto policy that is changed three months into the term. The cost splits and is prorated to price each coverage slice's effective dates.

The base rate is modified based on factors such as increased limits, deductibles and anti-lock brakes. The modifications result in an adjusted rate. The adjusted rate is usually based on a length of time rather than the term amount, so both the term amount and a calculation to find the adjusted rate per unit cost are needed. The rate used to develop a cost may be an adjusted rate created with an adjusted base value.

PolicyC enter will:

1. Look up the base rate and save it to the cost
2. Look up and calculate the adjusted rate and save it to the cost

NOTE regarding effective periods: If a cost needs to be determined for an effective period of time that does not match the standard rating period, either the Basis or the Rate must be adjusted to fit the effective period.

slides.title: Downstream system example: Billing system fa
slides.originalNotes:
Downstream system example: Billing system
A billing instruction is the set of directions from PolicyCenter to a billing system specifying transaction aggregations that must be acted upon. On receipt of the billing instruction, the billing system creates invoices or statements and processes them as needed to ensure the new premium is collected from the policy holder

The billing instruction does not encompass the whole policy. It simply provides information that is necessary for the billing process, such as account, policy, producer, and financial transactions.

slides.title: Transaction fields for earned premium
slides.originalNotes:
Transaction fields for earned premium
Reminder: The earned premium is the portion of the premium that applies to the expired part of the policy period. Insurance premiums are payable in advance, but the insurance company does not fully earn them until the policy period expires.

The written premium is the premium charged by an insurance company for the period of time and coverage provided by an insurance contract. The written premium depicts the amount of money placed on the books for the entire policy.

The unearned premium is the amount of premium remaining after deducting the earned premium from the written premium. Earned premium accrual refers to the method used for calculating an earned premium, which can vary across LOBs.

questionData.question: Describe the difference between the terms: rate scalable and basis
questionData.answer: Oo scalable.
